characters: FRANKENSTEIN WILL BE PLAYED BY MARY JANE WATSON.
DURING TONIGHT'S PERFORMANCE, THE ROLE OF ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: JIJJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dogs catching Frisbees in the park... Some fat old geezer playing chess... Autumn leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was thinking maybe the Bugle could show another side of New York for a change—-

dialogues.speaker: JIT
dialogues.text: Parker, if I believed for one second those pictures were an accurate reflection of this town, I'd hang myself from the top of the Chrysler Building. I don't pay you to be a sensitive artist! I pay you because for some reason that psycho Spider-Man will pose for you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, it's like I told you, Mr. Jameson. Spider-Man won't let me take any more pictures of him. He says you only use them to slander him. You've turned the whole city against him.

dialogues.speaker: JIT
dialogues.text: A fact I'm very proud of! Having that lunatic around has weakened the moral fiber of New York! The police are demoralized! The citizens lazy! Now get your pretty little "portfolio" out of my face before I go into a diabetic coma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jameson, please. You can't fire me. Even working two jobs I can barely make tuition, and Aunt May's social security doesn't amount to... JJJ mimes tying a noose around his neck, throws his head back, thrusts his tongue from his mouth. Peter folds.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What if--all right, what if I did have a shot of Spider-Man? Peter reaches into his knapsack and takes out a manila folder. Slides out a fantastic shot of Spider-Man saving nun from an oncoming meat truck. JJJ eyes it hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: JIT
dialogues.text: It stinks. I'll give you three hundred. He reaches for it. Peter snatches it back.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No. There's no way I can sell you this shot... until you agree to run more balanced coverage of Spider- Man.

dialogues.speaker: JIT
dialogues.text: I take my journalistic responsibility to present balanced coverage very seriously Parker, you know that. Fine. I'll give you four. I'll nominate him for a goddamn medal, Parker. You have my word.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Five.

dialogues.speaker: JIT
dialogues.text: That's outrageous. (beat) Done. Peter lets go of the photo, then sits a moment. Knowing h has just made big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: JJJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, you've wasted enough of my precious time, Parker. Get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time. Right. Peter snaps out of it, looks at his watch: oh, shit. He l to his feet, grabs his knapsack, and runs out. EXT. MINEO'S PIZZA — DAY Peter rides up on an elderly Kawasaki: RUMBLING, COUGHING SPUTTERING. Not a well machine. On the back, a hotbox wit the Mineo's logo. Peter leaps off and runs into the pizze A PAGER beeps. INT. MINEO'S — DAY Peter hurtles into the shop, out of breath, frantic. Yank the pager from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sorry! Mr. Aziz, I'm sorry. MR. AZIZ hangs up the phone. The BEEPING stops. Life has disappointed Mr. Aziz; Peter's only a side-manifestation.

dialogues.speaker: MR. AZIZ
dialogues.text: Twenty-one minutes ago, in comes an order from the high-quality law firm of Foehn, Harmattan & Buran for seventeen extra large deep-dish pizzas. In eight minutes, I am defaulting on the Mineo's twenty- nine minute guarantee. Indeed numerous banners and signs proclaim the sacred number. MR. AZIZ (cont'd) Then not only will I be receiving no money for these pizzas, I will lose the customer forever to Pizza Yurt. And they are killing me already.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why didn't you send Salim?

dialogues.speaker: MR. AZIZ
dialogues.text: Salim was deported yesterday. I have no hope but you. You must make it in time. He starts thrusting pizzas at Peter, stacking them in Pet arms until we can't see his face anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a nice young man, Peter, but you are not dependable. This is the last chance I can give you. You must cross forty-two blocks in seven and one half minutes. Or your ass is to be fired. Peter checks the big Mineo's clock. It's 5:44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter runs to his bike, dumps the pizzas into the hotbox. Climbs on, kicks it. Nothing. Kicks it again. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don't believe this! Mr. Aziz watches, contemplating suicide. Peter kicks it o more and it starts. He goes slobbering off. EXT. NEW YORK STREET — DAY Peter halted. Looks at his watch. 5:47. A van has collided with a Town Car. The DRIVERS are on th street, shouting and threatening each other. The PASSENGE gets out, too. The three men come to blows. Peter pops up onto the sidewalk. Mistake. An old lady ina wheelchair comes out of nowhere. Peter hits the brakes. Swerves. The bike stalls. He kicks wildly at the starter: dead. And it's 5:48. Peter leaps off the bike. With a mighty heave he wrenches hotbox right off the back of the motorcycle, snapping bol twisting metal. Then he ducks into an alley. EXT. LOWER MANHATTAN - NEW YORK STREET — AERIAL SHOT Spider-Man swings toward the Woolworth Building. One-hand since the hotbox is tucked under his left arm. At the end each arc he freefalls until he shoots the next strand of Below, two boys chase each other and a basketball into th street. A car is coming right at them. Spider-Man's spider sense tingles. He looks down; sees th trajectories of car, ball and boys, pure vectors of physi plotted against the air: collision. Spider-Man heaves the hotbox away. It arcs heavenward. Wi his hand now free, he shoots a strand of web. A lasso of web encircles the boys and yanks the boys towa the opposite side of the street.  Sets them on their feet. The car squeals past, horn BLARING. The boys, dazed. The basketball shoots in, a web-slung ch pass. One of them catches it. They look up at the sky. Spider-Man catches up to the hotbox as it hurtles earthwa past him. Snags it with a web and drags it back up. The Woolworth Building looms. Spider-Man snags its pinnacle a arcs around it, circling in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter rushes in with the stack of pizzas. Out of breath, of wild looking. A big, silly grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Pizza time! He sets the pizzas on the desk. The receptionist stares a him, then at the pizzas: disgust. Peter looks--there's a of webbing on the top box. Sheepish he scrapes it off.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. INT. MINEO'S PIZZA — EVENING Peter struts in, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mr. Aziz! I'm back! I-- Mr. Aziz whirls on him.

dialogues.speaker: MR. AZIZ
dialogues.text: You are fired, that is what you are. The pizzas arrived three minutes late! Peter, the twenty- nine minute guarantee is a promise. I know a promise means nothing to you, but to me it is serious.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's serious to me, too, Mr. Aziz. Honestly. Please, I need this job, please give me another chance. Mr. Aziz shakes his head. Peter gives up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's tired old Kawasaki pulls up in front of the build backfiring. He climbs off it.  Trudges into the lobby. SPIDER SENSE. Peter's surging HEARTBEAT. A shadow looms. Peter jumps back, then lashes out and grabs hold of his attacker. Ducks, twists, flips a very large man over his shoulder. The guy SLAMS against the lobby floor. It's a b SECURITY GOON. Peter has flattened the guy.

dialogues.speaker: GOON
dialogues.text: Christ, I think you broke my tailbone!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, man, I'm sorry, I--

dialogues.speaker: GOON
dialogues.text: I was only going ask for your ID!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: My ID? Since when--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter takes out his key. But instead of a keyhole there's card-reader. He's puzzled. The door flies open.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What the hell you did to my security guy?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He surprised me! I grabbed him and he... he must have lost his footing. (how lame!) I think they just waxed the lobby. (changing the subject) What's with the muscleman, Harry? Did somebody threaten you?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right? Pete, I'm lucky Spider-Man hasn't killed me already! He knows I'll spend every last dime I have to take him down.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Harry. I'm worried about you. You've really gotten kind of... He takes a slender hybrid PDA/remote from his pocket. Tap some buttons. Titanium bars slide across the windows. Steel shutters c down. Laser trip-beams spin a glowing web across the livi room. Another beam lances from the ceiling and performs a retinal scan of Peter. He flinches.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...paranoid. Harry holds up the screen of his super-Palm. It reads ID CONFIRMED: PARKER, PETER.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I guess you're who you seem to be.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Please just tell me you didn't put a camera in the bathroom. Harry taps, and all the barriers retract; the beams die. gets right in Peter's face. Trying to be funny but with w intensity.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You could save me a buttload of money and trouble if you would just tell me how you always manage to find the guy. .»PETER'S FACE The impossibility of the situation; the pain.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I would if I could. I swear to you. Harry stares at him, searching his face. Something there he doesn't quite believe. Peter struggles to meet Harry's searching gaze. Falters. Fails.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: That's fine. No, I'm serious. You don't need me, I don't need you. We're not even really friends, are we? Takes two tickets from his pocket, tosses them on the tab

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hear are those tickets you wanted. That Octavius guy at Columbia. Have fun.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Octavius! Otto Octavius is the god of arachnid biomimetics. Harry, I know you're mad at me, but come on! You can't miss that! Peter is perfectly serious. Harry can't help smiling.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Lord have mercy on my soul.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You promised you'd introduce me to him! The rage flares up again in Harry.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: And you promised to help me get Spider Man! (subsides ) All right, fine. I keep my promises.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Great! Okay! Let's bolt. They start to go out. Harry stops by the door, points to answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, there was a message. For you. I didn't feel like picking up. Peter goes to the machine, presses play.

dialogues.speaker: MJ'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello. This is Mary Jane Watson, star of the Broadway stage. (beat) You guys, I'm so nervous! Peter checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hmm. Geez, I hope the lecture's over by 7:30. I need to get down to the theater by 8.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Didn't you already see that lame show of hers?  10.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Twice.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Christ, Pete, I know you're her boyfriend, and all, but that's above and beyond.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, tonight she's playing the lead! She's the, you know, the understudy. As they walk out of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What, did she poison the leading lady?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Shut up. And I'm not her boyfriend. Bars descend, indicators flare, as they shut the door. INT. COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY — DAVIS AUDITORIUM — NIGHT Packed house of researchers, reporters, interested member the public. PROF. CZERNOWITZ is introducing Otto Octavius

dialogues.speaker: CZERNOWITZ
dialogues.text: .+.as a doctoral candidate he was dazzling. Now I'm afraid he's left us mere mortals far behind. It's my great honor to present, director of the Anansi Project, winner of a National Science Medal, Dr. Otto Octavius. APPLAUSE as Otto strides out. Younger than you might expe Wearing a long black Gaultier jacket. Smiling like a man with a surprise in store for us. He and Czernowitz meet. stiffness between them. Czernowitz looks intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNOWITZ
dialogues.text: Otto. They shake hands awkwardly. Then Otto strides to the podi Grins, self mocking. Behind him on a table, a violin and bow. Piano to one side.  Laughter. 11.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: He told you I was "dazzling," but what he's too nice to bring up is was what an insufferable little wretch I was. The lights dim; spot on Otto. Behind him a large flatpanel monitor descends. As he talks, the display will mirror, expand on and illustrate his words.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Biomimetics seeks to adapt for human use the technologies of other species. We poor humans have always envied our fellow creatures their talents; soon we will share them. Peter is rapt; Harry is playing Tetris on his Palm Pilot.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My own researches have been into arachnid technology: adapting, the remarkable abilities of spiders, their web-spinning abilities, their astonishing, almost precognitive impulse control. Harry notices how spellbound Peter is; leans over.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I will never understand this spider thing of yours. Peter takes no notice.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: We had some success with manipulating spider RNA. But it's in the area of octopedal locomotion that things are really getting exciting. The goal is to provide stable motion on every possible kind of terrain and superior manipulation at a distance. Otto steps out from behind the podium.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can't imagine the sheer number crunching might required to control and coordinate eight legs. Really tough. Actually, it was a chance visit to the Bronx Zoo that gave me the key insight.  12. He walks toward the monitor, which displays an octopus, a with a diagram of its nervous system.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The octopus has the equivalent of a powerful processor in each leg, networked to the central unit in her brain. The display fades to a diagram of the Rig, eight legs networked to each other through and to the center. The center is empty; then a diagrammatic human operator appea

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, so far the capacity to control the full complement of eight legs is beyond our capacity. But we've been able to implement a similar system using... Otto takes a step forward, smiling a little coyly. Then f somewhere behind him a pair of glinting pseudopods snake The black stealth-bomber glint of superhard ceramic. A ga from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Four! Harry sits up. Puts away the Palm Pilot. The 'pods hover over Otto's shoulders a moment, undulant.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I call it a self-articulating network, but I'm afraid the name that has stuck is Otto's Octopus. One 'pod reaches to tap him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes? Oh, thank you. It is a little warm in here. The arms help him out of the jacket, and as it comes off, another pair of pseudopods is revealed. The audience goes little nuts. One 'pod takes up the violin; another, the bow. The next snake out toward the piano; Otto strikes up a Grieg sonat With his own two hands, he takes out a fat cigar and ligh it; puffs contentedly. The audience, amazed, afraid, half suspecting that it's a prank.  13. Peter with a look of open-mouthed wonder. The music break off. Now the 'pods assume a configuration like a daddy long-le "toes" splayed against the dais, arching high into the ai Among them hangs, perfectly at ease, Otto. One at a time, turn, he raises and lowers each foot.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Each one of my four assistants here is equipped with its own hundred- teraflop processor. He begins to stride back and forth across the stage on hi four dancing pseudopods.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Computer architecture so sophisticated and capable of learning it approaches consciousness. He sinks back onto the two lower 'pods. The upper ones sn out around him.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At times I feel the Rig here has a life of its own. LEFT UPPER PSEUDOPOD takes a piece of paper from Otto's pocket. RIGHT UPPER produces a pen and scrawls something across the paper. Then the 'pod with the paper slaps it across Otto's back. He turns around, as if confused, walk on the lower pseudopods. The sign says GEEK! Laughter from the audience. They're eating this up. Otto, back to the audience, whirls his head around.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Given time, and a strong enough host... (rueful smile) ...its systems and my own would actually begin to integrate with each other-- The pseudopods rip away his shirt, revealing THE RIG nest right up against his spine, overlapping his own flesh.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --Merge into one organism.  14.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Shock, even revulsion at the sight of the implants. Then surge of APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Gapes, bowled over.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You have to introduce me to him!

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Don't you have a diva waiting? Peter checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto lurches in on the pseudopods to a ROAR of applause f the hall. The 'pods telescope in and Otto falls to the floor. But o of the 'pods remains slightly extended. OTTO'S team crowds around him and drag him over to the NE COUPLER UNIT. They mount it around him. The TEAM LEADER twists the Rig's LATCH. This is a dial wi glass tube at its heart, like a spirit level, with a sing glowing bubble of air. He aligns the bubble with a mark a WHAM-the 'pod LASHES out and knocks the Team Leader aside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are still applauding. But Peter's spider-sense TINGLES. He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'll meet you in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Where are you--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Too much coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rig is out of control. Otto hangs from it like a doll The pseudopods whip and buzzsaw. Smash lightbulbs. Scatte humans.  15. Spider-Man leaps into the middle of the cyclone. He tries reach Otto. The 'pods feint and block. He fires web snares at the pods; pins them to the wall. T break free, lash out. Knock Spider-Man down. Spidey leaps up, fires a strand in either direction, snag the upper two ‘pods. Yanks them toward himself. Ties them a knot. They GRIND in protest. Keeping a grip on the knot he-- Spins a thick cocoon around each of the lower ones, paddi each out until it's a gently flailing balloon. The Rig struggles for a moment, then powers down. Otto falls to t floor, the ‘pods knotted across him. Spider-Man kneels beside Otto. Making sure he's okay. The Team Members hurry over with the coupler. Spider-Man out of the way. The team gets Otto into i and the Team Le twists the Latch. SPLORCH. The rig pops open. Otto falls out. We see that Otto's bare, muscular back is enhanced by fou neural sockets. They roll him over. Otto opens his eyes. The irises of his eyes seem to be leaking into the whites: pinwheels. Strange flowers. Octo

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Look at his eyes!

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT 2
dialogues.text: We're overdoing the endorphin push.

dialogues.speaker: TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: That's the symbiosis routines in the Rig. It's actually trying to reconfigure his optical functions.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Was I... was I fighting Spider-Man? Everyone looks around at Spider-Man. Spider-Man's not the Otto sits up. They try to help him.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm fine! Thank you. I'm fine. Now, get off me. He stands up, shaky. Brushes off their helping hands.  16.

dialogues.speaker: TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: Otto, it was too long. You stayed in the Rig too long.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: No, the problem is that I didn't stay in it long enough! My system never gets the chance to reach equilibrium with the Rig's! They stare at him. Is he serious? He looks around. Sees t broken light bulb. The slashed curtain. The shattered cha He sits down.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe I stayed in the rig too long, I don't know. They bring him a glass of water and a clean shirt. He acc their ministrations.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thanks a lot, Teddy. (concerned) Are you all right? I didn't hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: (relieved) I'm fine, chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry introduces Peter to Otto; they're shaking hands. Ot looks a bit frazzled but basically fine.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Doesn't it hurt to be jacked into that thing?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Actually, thanks to the endorphin boosters it feels very good. Coming out's a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's so great to meet you. And the Rig's pretty--cool.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Still one or two-- (twitches his head) Kinks to work out. But basically sound.  17.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Actually, Doctor, I was hoping to hear you talk about the superspider research.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Ah. Well. Unfortunately we lost our funding for that project. I'm afraid it was rather poorly managed. And please... call me Otto. Any friend of the Osborns is my friend. The Rig's materials and kinetechnology is all Oscorp design and build. Norman Osborn was a huge supporter of my work. A steady and generous supporter. Not too mention a true original. A man, in a world of mediocrities. He's very sorely missed. At this mention of Norman, a shadow clouds Harry's face.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I hear you're into spiders.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's sort of a hobby.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: And you guys had a--field trip? To our lab last year? I hope that was interesting?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Changed my life.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Pete? Not that I really care, but don't you have an ego extravaganza to get to? Peter looks at his watch: it's 7:45.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Jeez! Oh, my God. I have to go. Now!

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Ego extravaganza?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's our friend--  18.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Your friend.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: --MJ. Mary Jane Watson. She's in this musical. She's the understudy and she's making her big debut in fifteen minutes. He shakes hands with Otto, then starts away.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ought to check it out, I bet you'd really get into it. EXT. MARTIN BECK THEATER — NIGHT The Marquee reads: BRIDE! Over it, enormous cutouts of Dr Frankenstein and the Bride. The name Deirdre DUNN plaster everywhere. A tour bus pulls up in front of the theater. The nameplat reads: MT. NEBO CENTER FOR ASSISTED LIVING. A BUNCH OF OL LADIES file out. We're with two of the ladies, SOPHIE and ROSE. As they en the lobby, they are each handed a program. Rose notices a leaf of paper poking from the program. Tug out.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you know it. Sixty dollars a ticket and we get the understudy.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Deirdre's probably in rehab again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frenetic stagehands make last minute changes. Actors loit in the wings. We travel down the wings, past actors and c who crowd the stairs, down to the dressing rooms. MJ WATSON sits at the mirror, making little adjustments t her makeup.  19. She's in costume as Elizabeth Frankenstein and holding a blond wig in her hands. RENARD, the actor playing HENRY FRANKENSTEIN, lounges beside her, calm where she's worried. He's very good-looking.

dialogues.speaker: RENARD
dialogues.text: Just remember, acting is reacting. Mo Got it. Clearly troubled rather than nervous. The door to the dressing room opens. MJ turns expectantly. ANOTHER ACTOR' there, costumed as an Angry Villager.

dialogues.speaker: MJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you check Will Call?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: The ticket is still there. MJ looks sad. Puts on the wig, tugs it straight, and smil at herself. Big theatrical smile. The show must go on. Renard pulls a chair over, sits down right beside MJ.

dialogues.speaker: RENARD
dialogues.text: Hey, cheer up. There's a TV crew here, you know. From New York 1. They heard about your big debut.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: How did they hear?

dialogues.speaker: RENARD
dialogues.text: I don't know. Somebody must have called them. Somebody who likes the way you... act. Flirting hard. He brushes a flake of mascara from her che

dialogues.speaker: RENARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, who is he, your Mr. No-Show?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: A friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: No. Just a friend. I thought he might want to see my debut, but I guess he doesn't.  20.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Eh, who needs him?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: (resolute) That's what I say. Who needs him? The STAGE MANAGER comes in.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: MJ? You ready? I/E. THEATER — NIGHT Peter tears into the lobby. Runs up to the theater door. burly USHER stops him.

dialogues.speaker: USHER
dialogues.text: Whoa. You can't go in there. Nobody seated once the performance begins. Points to a sign which confirms this.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: But I--

dialogues.speaker: USHER
dialogues.text: It's to help maintain the illusion.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I understand. But I have to get in there. Mary Jane Watson is a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: USHER
dialogues.text: And as far as I can tell, she is a very nice young lady. (beat) Nobody seated once the performance begins. You can go in at intermission.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: When's that?

dialogues.speaker: USHER
dialogues.text: (checks watch) About forty-two minutes from now.

dialogues.speaker: MJ'S CAST HEADSHOT
dialogues.text: Nice picture. A little sultry.  21. INT. THEATER — LOBBY - NIGHT It's on a wall by the front doors. Peter's gazing at the picture. Just kind of amazed by how pretty she looks. Spider-sense TINGLES. SIREN in the distance. Faint SQUEAL of tires. INT. THEATER — ONSTAGE - NIGHT MJ as Elizabeth with Renard as Henry F. Henry is singing big number, "I Created A Man." MJ emotes back at him. Her gaze strays toward the house. Right in the front row, a glaringly empty seat. Back on MJ. She sings.

dialogues.speaker: OUR TWO OLD LADIES
dialogues.text: Way at the at the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She's terrible. INT. THEATER — NIGHT SIREN is louder. Peter ducks out into the street. Somethi is happening and he needs to stop it. It's coming from ov on Broadway. A CAR flashes through the intersection of 45th and Ninth. Driving way too fast. In traffic. Skids. Smashes into a c Then another. Then keeps on going downtown. Two seconds later, one two three police cruisers. Peter looks back at the theater. Then at his watch. Then to the avenue.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's not your problem, Pete. It's the police's problem. It's not your problem.

dialogues.speaker: "CAR CHASE" SCENE, (CC)
dialogues.text: The car roars down the avenue, weaving in and out. The cruisers in pursuit. It's a rag-top; THREE GUYS. Two in the back with machine guns. Oh, like Spider-Man didn't see that coming! Spider flies elegantly through their fire. Snags the two shooter Pins them to light posts and hangs them out for the polic  22. Now Spider-Man turns to the DRIVER. Lands on the car. Is thrown off. Shot at. Keeps coming back. In the end he crawls under the car, comes over top, webs the Driver's gun. Manages to get them both out just befor the car slams into a big construction site dumpster and EXPLODES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO POLICEMEN come running over. Spider-Man lowers the po bastard down to them on a line, headfirst. They grab him cuff him. One leads him away. The other looks up at Spide Man.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN 2
dialogues.text: There's no way I can not arrest you for that.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN
dialogues.text: Duly noted. He fires a web and swings back uptown.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN 2
dialogues.text: It's a lot safer in jail, Spider- Man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spider-Man, swings back toward the theater. Spider sense TINGLES. His head snaps left. Atop a building nearby, the flash of a sniper's rifle. Th next instant a shot rings out. A bullet snips the draglin neatly in two. It goes slack and Spider-Man falls out of sky. Spider-Man plummets to the ground. A MOTHER is pushing TWINS in a stroller. Right under him. Moving like a diver he twists around. Fires a web that sn a small billboard across the street. He stops falling. The webbing peels the entire top sheet off the billboard, a single piece. Peter falls the last four feet or so. Man to arrest his fall, slamming his shoulder into the paveme Nearly hits the TWINS.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Maniac! Idiot! Peter stumbles to his feet. Two big BRUISERS rush him. On carries a pair of heavy-duty handcuffs. They're on him. They're big, but Peter handles them easily with a little kung fu. Then he looks up.  23. Scans the skies over Ninth Avenue. All quiet. There's not there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look. It's the ten million dollar man. Spider-Man looks down. And sees that a crowd has gathered around him. Most just staring at him like hungry dogs.

dialogues.speaker: TAUNTING MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We get five, six guys together, we could take him. That's like, what, two million apiece. Come on. But he doesn't step forward. Nobody steps forward. Then a little kid steps forward. Twelve or thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: You in for it now. The kid hands Spider-Man an early copy of tomorrow's Bugl THE PHOTO PETER SOLD HIM TODAY(captioned SPIDER MAN ASSAU NUN!!!) and THE HEADLINE: WANTED -- $10,000,000 REWARD.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN
dialogues.text: Ten million dollars. I should arrest myself. Bounds right over them and then into the night.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give it your best shot, New York. INT. MARTIN BECK THEATER — LOBBY - NIGHT Peter comes tearing back in. The lobby's ominously empty. same usher stands there. Ready for Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Tell me I didn't miss intermission. In reply the usher just crosses his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MJ is having a deep scene with the Monster and the Bride, just before the tragic conclusion.  24. At the back of the theater, one of the old ladies watches expressionless. Her friend is sound asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter waits, watching the door. Some actors come out. Pet perks up--no. Then she's there.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: She sees him, is pierced through by the sight of him--and keeps walking. He goes after her.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: MJ. Please. She keeps going. He takes her by the arm. She shakes it o She isn't going to even speak to him. On second thought-- turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: You know, when you said you wanted to be friends, I believed you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I do want to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Well, then you aren't a very good friend, are you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I tried, MJ. I got here. I mean, I was a little late. They wouldn't let me in.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: But you missed everything! All of it! Why didn't you come in at intermission? Peter doesn't know how to answer this; can't lie fast eno

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well--there was an accident--in the street. I went to get a picture and-- She doesn't want to hear it. Starts away again.  She looks 25.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: MJ. I do want to be your friend. I'm sorry. Please. at him. Is she softening? Peter will never know. Renard comes out of the theater. Checks out Peter. Gives her Pete. Her Peter the

dialogues.speaker: RENARD
dialogues.text: Good night, MJ. You were wonderful. a big hug. When he lets go, MJ is staring right at look says, See? You could lose me. Renard gives fisheye and then walks off.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: MJ. You aren't-- are you...

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Renard's just a friend. Why. Do you wish I was seeing somebody? Would you like to get rid of me and for all?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: No. No, I think you enjoy this idea you have that I'm going around carrying a torch for you. Which I'm not. (beat) No, I'm not seeing anybody, Peter. But you know what? I might meet someone. I might even fall in love with somebody. Tomorrow. And then nobody will be carrying a torch for you. And then what will you do? She's angry. He looks like he thinks she has a right to b

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: MJ. You don't know. You don't know how much I think about you. How much I--

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: No, that's right. I don't know anything. I've known you since the first grade but I don't know anything about you.  26. Peter takes a step toward her. Looks into her eyes. Six inches of air separates him from having her. His PAGER goes off. He's embarrassed, fumbles with it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sorry. It's--oh. It's Aunt May. She hardly ever pages me. I better-- MJ watches him go. Typical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's on the phone, worried.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Aunt May? Aunt May, what's the matter? Why are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt May's in her bathrobe, sitting at the kitchen table. so quietly losing it.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: What's the matter? I'm going out of my mind, that's what the matter! I can't take it any more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is distressed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, Aunt May, settle down. I'm coming. He hangs up, and runs back down to the alley where he lef MJ. But she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter races out to Queens on his lousy motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter comes running into the house at top speed, tears in the kitchen. Aunt May's just sitting there, not crying. Scarily still, holding a cup of tea, in a pool of light. Nice plate of cookies beside her.  27.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Aunt May? What--

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: There's a fly.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A fly?

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: A fly, a bee, I don't know what it is. Buzzing all around the house, it's driving me insane! Who can sleep with a racket like that? PETER: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: All right. I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: I tried to kill it myself, but I can't. I don't know where it is. Peter cocks an ear, his hearing spider-sharp.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's in the bedroom on your lamp. She gives him a look; how did he know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter steps into the bedroom and closes the door behind h His eyes dart to a porcelain shepherdess holding up a for watt bulb and a gilt-edged shade. There on the shepherdess's bonnet perches a big fat juicy fly. If we could detect such things, we would sense that fly feels a sudden alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt May hears the THWING of Spidey's webbing and then a SPLAT. Peter emerges from the bedroom, looking satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mission accomplished.  A beat. 28.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Peter. I know you must think I'm losing my mind. It's just-- your uncle always killed the bugs around here.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He was a handy guy to have around. (beat) I never realized how much I depended on his advice.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Something on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well--

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: You could talk to me, you know.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know that. But I--

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Peter... (taking a chance) I've seen the change that has come over you since Ben died. Everyone has. Peter looks startled. Guilty.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Change...? I don't... What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: You have to grieve him, Peter. You have to let yourself mourn.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. (beat) I wish I could.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh--no, I mean, I know, you're right.  29.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Sooner or later, Peter, you have to let it out. It might as well be now. Peter nods. Sits down. Weight of the world.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm having a very hard day, Aunt May. She slides the plate of cookies over to him. He takes one Chews it. Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Cry.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, Aunt May. I can't cry. I can't mourn Uncle Ben. I don't have the right.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, Peter. Of all people--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Of all people, not me. You don't know- everything there is to know, Aunt May. About how Uncle Ben died. The guy who-- that punk. (deep breath) I had a chance to stop him. MAY What?

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The guy. I ran into him. A couple of hours before he shot Uncle Ben. He was robbing this place. And I knew it. And I could have stopped him easily. But I let him run right past me. Because at the time it didn't seem like my problem. She's just looking at him. Dry-eyed. A little confused, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then like an hour later, that's when Uncle Ben was waiting for me and this guy went up to him and...  30. She sits a moment longer. Then she stands up and takes th plate of cookies away from him.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I can understand how you didn't want to tell me this. Turns and dumps all the lovely cookies into the trash. Qu fury.

dialogues.speaker: MAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, on the surface, it does seem to be something fairly unforgivable.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Aunt May? She swings the china plate above her head, then brings it down against the counter. It shatters.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Damn it! She crouches stiffly and begins to pick up the pieces. Pe goes to help her but she pushes him away. As she tosses shards into the trash, she cuts herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ow! Damn it. Pokes her finger into her mouth. Peter tries to put his h on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get away from me. Get out! He backs away. She takes the Dustbuster from the broom cl and begins noisily to bust dust. Steely eyed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Aunt May-- She ignores him, vacuuming. He turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter roars back to the city. As he slows in some traffic the bike begins to backfire and throw sparks. Then it actually bursts into flame. Fellow motorists honk at him. leans out of a passing car.  31.

dialogues.speaker: FELLOW MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Yo, butthead, your motorcycle is on fire. Peter scrambles over onto the shoulder. Leaps off the bur bike. Contemplates the flames then starts to stamp them o This quickly devolves into a vicious kicking.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Stupid frigging piece of junk! Why can't I have one thing in my life that actually works! Fellow motorists slow their cars to watch as Peter's spid strength renders the bike a heap of junk in seconds.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can't-- even-- cross town without bursting into flames-- or being shot at! Peter stands over the corpse of the bike, heart POUNDING. Then turns and starts to limp home along the median. INT. OSBORN/PARKER APARTMENT — NIGHT Harry is lying on the couch, watching a tape of Barbara Walters interviewing the his father. With the aid of a sh of martinis. And a little amber prescription bottle. THUMPING from outside, muffled through the blast shutter the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, god damn it, let me in! Harry picks up the remote and punches in the code. The barrier goes up. Peter drags his sorry ass in the door. H a wreck.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I made martinis.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I see that. Onscreen, Norman Osborn sheds a single shining tear. Harr crying, too.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: That's the only time that man ever cried.  32.

dialogues.speaker: PETER'S FACE
dialogues.text: Oh, brother. Here we go. He takes a deep breath, then sits down beside Harry.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have a drink. You look like you could use one.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I probably could. But no, thanks. He points to the bottle of pills.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are those?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Dinner. Courtesy of Dr. Chomsky.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm sure he doesn't want you taking them with alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: She. No, you're right. She'd probably be very disappointed in me. They sit and watch the tape of Norman Osborn. Now Norman his old in-control self again, telling Barbara Walters a story. Barbara is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pete. Just tell me where to find him. Tell me where you meet him. That's all you need to do. I'll take care of the rest. Peter looks at him. Harry just keeps staring at the scree

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can't. He broke off contact with me. He said I've made it too dangerous for him. He almost got killed today.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I know. (beat) Who do you think put up the bounty? Onscreen, Norman Osborn is laughing, now, too. A strangel familiar laugh. His goblin grin is reflected for a moment his son's face, mad glint of the TV in his eye.  33.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Bounty!

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, did I say bounty? I meant reward.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Harry, what you're talking about is--

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Murder? Maybe. People get murdered, Pete. My father. Your uncle. It happens. The tape goes blank. Harry's eyes fill with static. Peter gets up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I think--it would probably be best for me to move out.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What? Because of what I said about Spider-Man? Pete, don't be--

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mr. Aziz fired me today, Harry. And I can't work for the Bugle anymore. So. I can't afford to pay you rent anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You'll find another job. I'll carry you until you do, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I couldn't let you do that. Harry sloshes upright. Grinning a twisted grin.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: No, that's right. You wouldn't want to be a sniveling little do-nothing freeloader. Like me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Harry, come on. Let's not--ah, forget it. He starts to walk out.  34.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Pete? Harry sits up, drunk and stoned but still Harry.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well... where are you going to go? Home to Aunt May?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I don't think I'm so welcome there anymore. He climbs up to his bedroom door. Tries to open it. Pushe some buttons. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harry, could you please let me into my bedroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto lies in a steaming bathtub, recuperating from his sh Nice tub, good cigar. TV flickering in the wall. On the news: His performance. Video coverage of the lectu of Otto strutting around the stage.

dialogues.speaker: BOY TALKING HEAD
dialogues.text: ...potential applications, Octavius said, range from handling nuclear waste to detonating underwater mines to the exploration of outer space.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL TALKING HEAD
dialogues.text: Speaking of creepy crawlies, Jim, it seems that Spider-Man is finding New York to be a very tough town. At the words "Spider-Man" Otto sits up in the tub. He lea out, dripping, and pads over to the television wall. Otto hits the record button on his DVD-R. We see several shelves of DVD archives arranged above the recorder. On TV, the incident is reported. Jameson is there, rantin We see the headline about the reward. Then there's a shot Spider-Man scaling a wall. Otto zooms in on it, watching with a scientist's eye. The girl talking head comes back on.  35.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL TALKING HEAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was a scene right out of All About Eve tonight when a spokesman for Deirdre Dunn announced that the Broadway star, currently playing the lead in the popular musical Bride! would be taking a temporary leave of absence for some well needed rest... Otto pops out the disk, fits it into its box, scrawls a label. Files it on the shelf. We see that it is labelled: SPIDER-MAN 5/24/04. All of the other disks are labelled t same way. They go back for a year.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL TALKING HEAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-Said that the role will be played by Miss Dunn's understudy, Mary Jane Watson. Otto's attention is drawn to the screen again. MJ is bein interviewed, in makeup, backstage.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is great opportunity for me, but mostly I just wish for a very speedy recovery for Deirdre. Otto's gaze remains scientific, but somehow softened. Tow off his hair, watching MJ's lovely face. We pull back and reveal as we do so his four backjacks, e capped with a rubber seal, glistening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day's Bugle: NEW YORK TO SPIDER-MAN: DROP DEAD. EXT. NEW YORK STREET — NEWSSTAND - DAY The newspaper sits atop a pile. THWIP! A fine mesh of webbing spreads across the edge of the paper. The NEWSVEN watches openmouthed as the paper is tugged gently skyward A dollar bill comes dangling down on a thin silky thread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spider-Man crouches atop the lamppost, scanning the paper Crumples it up. Head snaps to the left. TINGLE of spider sense. A GUNSHOT. A SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A THUG runs out with a sackful of money. Stuffs his gun i his waistband. A jet of webbing catches his left arm and pins it to the wall. Another catches his right arm, then THWIP-THWIP eac his legs at the ankle. He's pinned and struggling. He drops the bag. Spider-Man picks up the bag. Opens it and peers inside.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN
dialogues.text: You shot someone for nineteen dollars? That's-- Out of nowhere looms a huge OBJECT, heading for his skull wet impact. It's a WATERMELON, wielded by a pair of YOUNG MEN. A neat stack of watermelons behind them. Spider-Man wobbles. Sags.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: You're under arrest. The GROCER comes running over. A bloody patch on his uppe arm. Picks up the bag of money. Screams at the young men.

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you? He's a good guy. I'm sorry, Spider-Man. Here. He jabs the grubby pile of bills toward Spider-Man. A SIR Spider-Man closes the Grocer's hand around the money.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN
dialogues.text: (to Grocer) Thanks. As the police run up, Spider-Man takes to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusk outside Bingo Hall. A black Volvo pulls up. Five HOO pile out and go running in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred frightened but outraged old Filipina ladies relinquish their bingo money to the pillowcases of the ho A thick strand of webbing lances in and SMACKS the gun of Lead Hood. Snatches it from his hand. Then swings it into his temple, knocking him cold.  37.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN
dialogues.text: Stands in the doorway, wielding the web like a lariat. The gun flies through the air, conking the Second Hood on head, then the Third, Fourth and Fifth. They all go down under three seconds. The old ladies turn to Spider-Man. Hard to read their expressions. He waves his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: OLD LADY
dialogues.text: Ten million dollars! They start toward him, and then they're on him, bludgeoni him with their handbags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stumbles free of them and then leaps to safety. INT. JJJ'S OFFICE — NIGHT JJJ's working late. Studying two alternate front pages. O says: NOWHERE TO RUN TO, BABY. The other says: NOWHERE TO HIDE. CRASH! !!!! A blizzard of broken glass. JJJ ducks under h desk as the avalanche comes down. Spider-Man drops down through the skylight over JJJ's des JJJ comes out from under the desk. Sees Spider-Man standi there.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN
dialogues.text: Got a minute? JJJ picks up his phone. Punches a button.

dialogues.speaker: JIT
dialogues.text: This is Jameson. Code S. Repeat. Code S.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN
dialogues.text: Is that S as in "Shut the hell up"? He slaps a gob of webbing across JJJ's mouth, then, in a seconds, encases him entirely. A slick pupa. Takes the straw from JJJ's Big Gulp. Picks up the cocoon. Jams in t straw about where JJJ's mouth should be. Garbled CURSING. Spider-Man sticks the cocoon under his arm and leaps to t  38. ceiling. Clambers across the newsroom, over the astonishe staff. Out a window, upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spider-man rips the cocoon away. JJJ starts to rant but l over the cornice and sees the street far below. Cringes a pulls back. Afraid.

dialogues.speaker: JIT
dialogues.text: I-- I'm acrophobic. Fear of heights.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER-MAN
dialogues.text: Really, I thought that was fear of spiders. (beat) Look, Jameson. I'm fine with you hating me. I'm even fine with you slandering me. But getting me killed, I don't know, that kind of irritates me a little. JJJ creeps carefully away from the edge.

dialogues.speaker: JIT
dialogues.text: The Bugle didn't tell anybody to kill you. His courage returning. He starts to close in on Spider-Ma

dialogues.speaker: JJJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, pal. I'm not fine with anything about you. You are a danger to this city. You may not believe in old-fashioned ideas like due process and the rule of law, but I do. You come in here with your tight pants and your sticky fingers and you tell us you're a hero. But you know what I see? A vigilante, a muscle man, a gangster in spandex. What gives you the right? Because you're the strongest? That's not the country I'm from. JJJ has Spider-Man on the defensive--backing away.

dialogues.speaker: JJJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I hired a psychiatrist to do a profile of you. Did you see that story? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JIJJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you read what that lady said? "Delusionary." "Narcissistic." "Messiah complex." Translation: JJJ goes in for the kill.

dialogues.speaker: JJJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need to get a life, pal. A door SLAMS. A DOZEN SECURITY GUYS pour out onto the roo Spider-Man looks at them, then back at JJJ. Seems about t speak. Then leaps over the side of the building, and is g The security men run to the ledge.

dialogues.speaker: JJJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where the hell were you? You're all fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter has his stuff packed up; he's carrying out three suitcases and big laundry sack. Harry comes out into the to watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: So, that's it. You're just going. Peter starts to say something, then just nods.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I found a place out in Sheepshead Bay. As he goes out the door, the laundry bag tumbles from the pile of suitcases. Peter stoops to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You don't have to take dirty clothes. You can still do your wash here, you know. Peter shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I need the big machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 AM. Deserted. Peter sits in a plastic chair, reading a thick tome entitled Biomolecular Chemistry.  40. A pile of similar tomes beside him. Makes a note in a notebook. A YOUNG MAN enters, carrying a laundry sack. Sees Peter sitting there. Peter doesn't look up. The man goes over t a machine. Spider sense TINGLES. Peter looks up as in slow motion th man walks, KEYRING JINGLING, CHANGE in his pocket, earpho THROBBING in his ears. Slowly the fingers reach for the lid of the machine.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No! The man gapes at him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can't use that one. That's my machine. The man decides that Peter is mad. He begins to stuff his clothes back into the sack.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Okay, mister. Take it easy. He shoulders the bag and hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The yellow light's flashing. Peter waits a moment, then runs over to the machine. The OUT OF BALANCE light is blinking. Peter lifts the lid Pulls out the red and blue suit, soaking wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry sits facing Dr. Chomsky, a petite Korean-American woman.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CHOMSKY
dialogues.text: Nightmares?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Every night. Two of them, last night.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CHOMSKY
dialogues.text: What are they about?  41.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I didn't think you guys handled dreams anymore. I thought that dreams were just brain garbage.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CHOMSKY
dialogues.text: They are. But you can learn a lot about a person by going through their garbage. Harry thinks. He closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY'S NIGHTMARE
dialogues.text: He's shaking hands with his father. They're both smiling. Then with a horrible wet sound Harry splits open, right d the center, and Norman Osborn steps out of the husk. The Norman starts to laugh his GOBLIN laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON HARRY
dialogues.text: He opens his eyes. Real pain in them.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: They're disgusting. I don't want to talk about them. Just, please. Give me something to help me sleep through them. The doctor stares at him. Sighs. Reaches for the prescrip pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto sits in the fifth row, center. Watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MJ sings her big number, "The Mind of the Man I Love."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto's entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MJ stalks offstage to lackluster APPLAUSE. Dissatisfied. Renard follows right behind.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: I sucked!

dialogues.speaker: RENARD
dialogues.text: You sucked not.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MJ runs into the dressing room, flings herself onto a battered sofa. There's a Bugle lying there; she tosses it toward Renard.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: The Bugle was right. I do "manage to be both overstated and paper- thin at the same time."

dialogues.speaker: RENARD
dialogues.text: Someone doesn't agree with you or the Bugle. He points to a big bouquet of black roses, with a card. S goes to them, intrigued, charmed, irritated all at once. Opens the card.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: If Peter thinks he can...

dialogues.speaker: THE CARD
dialogues.text: It reads: I THINK YOU ARE BRILLIANT. 0.0.

dialogues.speaker: RENARD
dialogues.text: Oh oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MJ is walking out, carrying the flowers. Otto approaches, keeps a certain distance. He doesn't want to frighten her He's dressed with a sharpness that is only slightly funer

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Miss Watson? She turns, startled but somehow having expected it, too.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm Otto Octavius. I--I sent you those flowers.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Oh oh.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: I hope that wasn't out of line. Was it? It was. Excuse me. I'm sorry.  43. He turns and walks away. Shaking his head. Not so much embarrassed as disturbed by the failure of his experiment

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: No! I mean--

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: I won't bother you again.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Wait! Slowly Otto turns back.

dialogues.speaker: MJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I loved the flowers. I've been sort of hoping somebody might send me flowers.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Peter Parker?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Yeah...? How do you...?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Peter's a friend. Of a friend. Honestly, I don't really know him very well at all. But he's the one who told me about you. About your being in this show. Which I loved. It was beautiful. You were brilliant, I meant it.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Thank you. Unfortunately the drama critic of the Daily Bugle doesn't agree with you.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: The man is a well-known idiot.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Legendary. She likes this. The bubble of weirdness between them pops can almost hear it. MJ salutes him with the roses.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Thanks for these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MJ and the roses go very well together. Otto stares. Inne turmoil visible. A long beat goes by. She turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Do you believe in the value of boldness, Miss Watson?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: At all times.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Have dinner with me. Right now. MJ hesitates. Not because she doesn't want to; because sh does. This is a big yes for her.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Where did you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: There's this Ethiopian place on West 47th.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Ethiopian. Wow. I've never-- He wiggles his long elegant fingers. Faintly but disturbi tentacular.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: I like to eat with my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lovely server settles an enormous platter of doro wat a other fine and strange foods before them. Otto is delight to see it. MJ less sure.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Yum. Look at that.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: It's very... colorful. Otto digs in. After a moment MJ tears off a piece of njer and joins in. Warily. Otto watches her. She looks right b at him.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Strange but good.  45.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: You were telling me about your mother.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: I know I was, and I'm sorry. Let's talk about you. You seem like a much more interesting person than me.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Not to me. (self mocking) Not right now, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are sitting closer to each other. She's finishing a story. It's supposed to be funny but he just nods, seriou

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: And did you have a dog?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: When I was little. Tasha. She--no. I am not going to tell you about my childhood pets. That's enough. It's your turn. Tell me about what you do. It sounds fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: I could describe it to you. But you would never believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what. Come uptown. Right now. I'll show you the lab. I'll show you the rig.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Oh, I couldn't--

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Boldness in all things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The darkened laboratory. Machines softly interrogate one another. KEY in the door. Slash of light.  46. All the lights go on as Otto ushers MJ in. She notices th rig right away. It hangs in its dock, a malign orchid.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Is that it? Otto is in love with the rig, of course. The way that a m might be in love with a ship, or a 1971 Chevrolet Barracu

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: That's it. She gets that he has feelings for his machine.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. (beat) It's a little freaky.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Well, I'ma little freaky. You should probably know that about me.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIG
dialogues.text: One of its heads. The one with a somehow crafty expressio its staring black sensor.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIG
dialogues.text: As Otto "comes out" to MJ.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: I am not like other people, MJ. I'm not like anybody you've ever met. Freaky, yeah, I'm a freak of nature. I taught myself calculus when I was nine. I was a chess grandmaster at fifteen. I don't say it as a boast. It was hell on earth. I had to fight every day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: I knew a kid like that.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: But there was always that one pretty girl who also managed somehow to be nice. I'll bet that was you, huh?  47. MJ looks away, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIG
dialogues.text: Deep in its sensor, a diode pulses. Now it's watching MJ.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Today, I'm all right with it. I've learned to embrace being a freak. I accept that I was given the gift of intelligence for a purpose. Which is this thing you see. The rig. Otto's Octopus. He goes over to it. Takes hold of one of its hands. A tou of the bridegroom.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: What does it, well... do?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Oh, it cuts hair. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What does it do? It improves you. It makes you better.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: You mean it makes you stronger?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Stronger, faster, yes, but also smarter. Much smarter. When I'm jacked in, I feel like my grasp finally equals my reach. I can feel myself--expanding. Not just my physical grasp but my mind, my heart, my soul. I feel enlarged by the experience. And it feels right. Have you ever felt anything like that?

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: I thought so. One time. She goes over to the rig. Slowly extends her fingers towa the nearest head. As her fingers draw nearer the diode pu and we begin to fear for the fate of her fingers. Her fingertips touch-- the eye goes dark.

dialogues.speaker: MJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When you say "jack"...  48.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: There are four shunts that interface directly with my central nervous system. I wear it. But it's also wearing me. He reaches up and takes hold of the latch, with its spiri level bubble.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the neural integrity seal. The latch, basically.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Does it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: The system delivers a steady dose of pain blocking endorphins the whole time I'm in it. Which so far has never been longer than a few hours. The goal is a permanent interface. Of course the idea of a permanent human/machine integration makes some people uneasy. Granted, MJ's looking a little uneasy. Otto fingers the Latch.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Rig is designed to seek to implement a systems merger with the host. Unfortunately, so far, my flimsy human tissue's not up to the challenge. Not yet. We're working on that. MJ is freaked, and fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: So you have, like... holes? In your back? Permanent ones?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Want to see them? Daring her, a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Not really, but yes. He turns. Unbuttons his shirt. Lowers it. Four black glin discs in his back. Freaky but beautiful.  49.

dialogues.speaker: MJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa! Okay. Thank you. Very nice. He pulls up the shirt, rebuttons it, turns. Shirttails hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: It's late.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FINGER scans the names. Stops at WATSON. Press the BUZZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's standing there. Dressed up. Holding a single red rose. He waits. There's no answer. He checks his watch; i late. Then cue the TINGLE of spider-sense. He whirls, hea FOOTSTEPS, VOICES. MJ and Otto approach the building. Peter's face as he registers the voices: alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the front step as MJ and Otto approach. Peter's not th MJ turns to Otto, carrying the big dark bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Thank you. I had a really nice, really interesting time. And thank you for the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: PETER PARKER
dialogues.text: Clings to the side of her building, upside down. Takes th single cheap rose from his teeth. Looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: So, maybe it's out of line. For me to ask you this. But I don't want to make a fool of myself. Are you seeing Peter Parker? Because if you are--

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: No. I was. But he wouldn't... He couldn't... He just couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: It's really none of my business.  50. But he looks pleased with the information. He holds out h hand.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good night. She takes his hand, then plants a kiss on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Watching the kiss. It's breaking his heart.

dialogues.speaker: MJ
dialogues.text: Turns and lets herself into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She presses herself against the door. Stunned at her own brazen behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Otto turns and starts back across town. A skip in his step. A cybergoth Gene Kelly. Feels like dancing with a lamppost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Otto walks through its beam we notice a dark shape crouching on the stanchion. Watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The domed building where it all began for Peter. A shadow from the shadows leaps onto the domes. It's Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great central hall. It's deserted and dim. He walks around. Hears echoes of that afternoon a year ago. The spider cages are empty. He looks down at his hand where the spider bit him, rubs Thoughtful, then his face breaks. He sits down, buries hi face in his hands. Chokes up. A WHIRR; he looks up, TINGLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter creeps down the hall just outside. We HEAR the unmistakable WHIRR of the rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1) Otto lowers the Rig into position. 2) The Rig watches, expressionless. 3) Otto steps into the Rig. Engages the coupler. A WHINE hydraulics. Otto reaches back to twist the Latch. Can't quite see wha his fingers are doing. His fingers can't reach. Can't reach. He strains, gruntin Gives up. Starts to press the decoupler. Then-- --a 'pod reaches in for the Latch and TWISTS IT. Otto flinches, then lets go as blessed relief floods his features. Sinking in. The irises of his eyes spiral out. One of the 'pods reaches toward his face and, tenderly, strokes it with steely finger. Peter, watching, GASPS. The 'pods hone in on the sound at once, quivering. Otto l over.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Who's there? Peter steps out of the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Parker?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: (rattled) What the hell are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you. But I see you're--what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: I was just--uh. Celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You use that thing... recreationally?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: It helps me relax.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits across a desk from Otto. One 'pod puts on a CD Two others are busy pouring two cans of Coke. Peter eyes ‘pods warily. Otto taps at the keyboard of his computer.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: The viral delivery system we were using in the superspider project.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That's right. Otto hits a few more keys.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: That's why you came here.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What other reason would there be? Otto shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Here. Yes, we were using a modified arbovirus. Highly infectious in spiders. We replaced the nucleonic RNA with whatever we wanted to code for and the virus did the rest.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is this arbovirus infectious in humans?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: It could be. If we had wanted to introduce spider material into a human, I suppose we could just have just gotten one of the little critters to bite-- Staring at Peter. Understanding without knowing.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: THE RIG
dialogues.text: It watches Peter and Otto, pulsing softly.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Why do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm just curious.  53. As Peter says these words: They are processed by the suit; it subjects them to a

dialogues.speaker: VISUAL VOICE-STRESS ANALYSIS
dialogues.text: The pattern is scanned and designated COUNTERFACTUAL. AN INDICATOR begins to blink on one of the pods.

dialogues.speaker: AT OTTO'S WORKSTATION
dialogues.text: The ROUTER begins to blink in kind.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MONITOR
dialogues.text: Windows pop up, running archive footage of Spider-Man: climbing, swinging, leaping. Another window: Superspider Inventory: 1 through 15. Numb 15 flashes: LOST. But Otto's not even looking at the monitor; he doesn't ne to.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Spider-Man's a friend of yours, isn't he? Peter starts to play the question off.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, not a friend--

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Know anything about him?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not much. Kind of a quiet guy.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Know if he was ever bitten by a spider?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He might have been. I wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: We lost a spider. If, by chance, it bit him. Is that what happened? And transferred the viral genotrope in its venom... He's advancing on Peter now. The ‘pods billow and arc.  54.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's great! It's a conceptual breakthrough!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not to him, it isn't. He's sick of it. That's why I came to see you. To see if there's any way to--

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Why didn't he just come himself?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, because. He's, uh, horribly disfigured. Up close. That's why he wears the mask. (shudders ) It's like, he has these little hairs all over him, and compound eyeballs. And the smell!

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Unfortunate. No way to control the process, I suppose, relying on a bite. (beat) He could probably use one of these eventually. He reaches into a tray behind him. Holds up a tiny ziploc bag with a speck inside. Peter leans in to look. A tiny b of circuitry--a spider-mite of silicon.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: It's basically an immune system on a chip. You seed it with a sample of the material you want to defend against, and it pumps out antigens. I call it a parity chip.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Parity?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Equilibrium. The Rig is so powerfully integrative that right now it overwhelms my own systems. I'm hoping to use this to boost my body's immunity. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In theory your friend could seed this with some of his own spiderized DNA, implant it, and knock out the genes that are coding for his spider traits. He tosses the chip back onto the tray.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is just a prototype. We're not in fab yet. Peter regards the tray, the little baggie. There it is. H salvation. His eyes stray up to:

dialogues.speaker: AN AIRVENT IN CEILING
dialogues.text: Conveniently located just over the tray.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had dinner with Mary Jane Watson tonight. Peter looks back, caught by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. I know.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Terrific girl.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rig is back in the coupler. Otto is at his workstatio asleep in his chair. All quiet.

dialogues.speaker: THE AIRVENT
dialogues.text: A tiny thread drops from it. Weighted with little suction cup of webbing. The little fishing line drops into the tray. Bounces. Mis the baggie. Bounces again. Snags it. THWIP! The baggie shoots up into the air and through the slats of the vent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter walks in, trying to appear nonchalant.  56.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes, hello. I need some soft tissue xx. And a Y-gauge syringe.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: A Y-gauge... what are you trying to treat, a rhinoceros?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A spider. (beat) Really big spider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter drops a box filled with lab supplies onto his tiny desk. Sweeps everything off the top of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny house in Brighton Beach. DITKOVICH is playing card for money, with his Ukrainian cronies. HUGE CLATTER. They look up at the ceiling. Then at Ditkovich.

dialogues.speaker: DITKOVICH
dialogues.text: (in Ukrainian, subtitled) The new roommate. They go back to their game. SOMETHING BREAKS. Ditkovich l down his cards with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: DITKOVICH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Ukrainian, subtitled) I think he took my vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ditkovich calls up as we climb the stairs and start down upstairs hall.

dialogues.speaker: DITKOVICH
dialogues.text: Mr. Parker? Everything is all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is wiping down the glass surface of the desk with Clorox. We see: gauze pads, adhesive tape, alcohol, pipet A hot plate with a saucepan of boiling water. A box of Morton's kosher salt. A bottle of vodka.  57.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes! Everything's fine! Sorry! He decants some of the steaming saline into a tube. He picks up the pipette, scrapes at the inside of his che Then he picks up the chip with a clasp. Smears the tissue against the chip. Drops it into the tube. Holds up the BIG NEEDLE. Jeez. Pokes it down into the tub and draws in the fluid. The chip is sucked in along with He stares into the whirling fluid in the syringe.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: In its swirl: 1) Spider-Man careens like a maniac through Greater Manha airspace. 2) Peter Parker sits despondent in Otto's laboratory, hea his hands. 3) He crouches at the side of Ben Parker, watching him di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd taught you the meaning of responsibility, Peter. At least by my death. That's the part of all this that makes me the saddest. Peter turns. Uncle Ben is sitting on the bed behind him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You don't know what it's like, Uncle Ben. You don't know how it feel to be such a freak of nature! Okay, with great power comes great responsibility. I get that. But you know what comes with no power? No worries. No guilt. No freak show! With his free hand he pours a shot of vodka. Tosses it ba

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not going to lose Mary Jane because of Spider-Man. I can be Spider-Man, or I can have a life. A normal life. And drawing a deep breath he jerks up his shirt, baring h hip.  58. Pops the needle under the skin. Squeezes. It hurts. A lot His eyes roll back in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLINK of coins. A muffled THUD from above. Play stops. Ditkovich starts to say something. Changes his mind.

dialogues.speaker: DITKOVICH
dialogues.text: Hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter wakes up on the floor. Sits up. Hand to his hip; a dimple under the skin. He checks himself out in the mirror. Strong. Fit. No visi difference. He frowns, then leaps up into the air. Comple a half-flip, and sticks feet first against the ceiling. D He dresses with care, buttoning his neat civilian clothes Then he goes to the closet.
